title: Who benefited from the breakup of Yugoslavia? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well…. none of us did benefit much. What you read was correct. There are some positive changes comparing current states to Yugoslavia, but truth be told Yugoslavia was economically on the path to gradual economic reform towards more market oriented economy and more economic freedom in the late 80-ties anyway - it’s just that this was overshadowed by political developments. You see, when Milošević started making waves in 1987/88/89, the other republics were increasingly worried about the direction Yugoslavia was headed. He and his followers wanted to change Yugoslavia to be more unitary, in a nutshell, (the talks regarding reforming the 1974 constitution which failed due to opposition from other republics predate him, but he wasn’t going to just accept failure) which was initially resisted by other republics, particularly Slovenia and Croatia which at first sought to maintain the status quo, and later on wanted change - in the opposite direction. It didn’t have to break down, and it especially didn’t have to break down as it did; the final point at which an agreement could have been reached and Yugoslavia could have been, theoretically, preserved -in a changed, compromise, form-, was the 14th party congress of the SKJ in January of 1990. This was not to be and Yugoslavia was de facto finished at that point. It took some more time to formally die, but the moment republic leaderships stopped talking to each other, Yugoslavia was finished. War would follow soon. Who benefited? Well, I guess in a larger geopolitical sense the west did benefit from a independent non-western country going down under , but I’m not much for conspiracy theories, if you are going in that direction, in my opinion the decisive factor of the breakup, and of such violent breakup in particular, was just short sighted Balkanic stupidity. Also, we believed, somewhat foolishly, that if only we adopted democracy and capitalism that we’d be “like Switzerland”. Didn’t go that way, suffice to say… ———————— Edit: just to be clear, the socialist system had to go; it wasn’t working well anymore, and it wasn’t working well for quite some time as evidenced by the crisis in the 80-ties, but again, with Marković’s reforms it started moving towards sounder economics. Keeping Yugoslavia “as it was”, both politically and economically, was not an option really acceptable to anyone anymore. I am however convinced that a more gradual shift to a capitalist economy would have worked better than the whole “let’s privatize everything while the war is going on so nobody sees what’s happening” business, and that a more loose confederation type of association with political liberalization would have retained the good things, while disposing of most of the bad ones.

Only a few had received benefits, but boy, did they benefit. Breakup of Yugoslavia was caused by and followed by formation of new elites. Public property became property of the state, and was sold to various ‘businessmen’ with strong political connections.  Businessman Ivica Todorić with Franjo Tuđman, president of Croatia Here’s a translated exempt one conversation between ex-prime minister Hrvoje Šarinić and president Franjo Tuđman about most prominent businessmen of Croatia at the time, Kutle and Todoric [1]: Sarinic: Monopoly of media, monopoly of economy, monopoly of banking, all that supported by politics, pardon me, but that’s not a democratic option. This is not my option, this is not my worldview. I can not stand that, mr. President. Ivica Todoric is more solid men for me then Kutle. Kutle is a mere primitive. Kutle could never build his empire without Pašalić (a high-ranking politician of ruling party HDZ), you can see that from outer space. Tudjman: Let me tell you the other side - Kutle’s empire would not exist without Pasalic, not just without Pasalic, but without HDZ, OK, but HDZ would not come to existence without Kutle. This is how Crony capitalism works - businessmen financing politicians, who return the favor by granting favors. On highest levels, presidents and prime ministers grant state-wide monopolies to their champions. But the rule with these businessmen is, eventually they loose political support, and their businesses can’t survive without it. Both of above Kutle and Todoric have lost their empires, causing state-wide and even region-wide economic crisis in the process. But worry not, they didn’t end up poor. On the contrary, they kept all their private riches, and none of their families and their descendants will have to work a day in their lives, ever. So that’s an example from Croatia, but it’s easy to find similar examples in other ex-Yugoslavian countries. In Bosnia there was Bobar, owner of banks, insurances, whatnot, fell out of favor, lost everything. In Serbia there was Živanov who owned plenty of food industries, and had monopoly on chicken, fell out of favor, landed in jail. Etc. But in the end, overall economic damage caused by these political-economic games surpasses economic damage caused by wars. Now, not all of these state-favored businessmen went bankrupt and/or ended up in jail, some actually do lead good businesses. But it’s still far below efficiency of free market. Overall, it’s a few hundreds families that made serious profits. [1] ŠTO JE TUĐMAN MISLIO O HRVATSKIM TAJKUNIMA?
